{
    "id": 7728967,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/1883",
    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1285 on 2009-11-05 by trac user cgranade, assigned to unknown._\n\nWhen compiling Fortran code that uses quadruple precision with the f2py tool, I get the following errors:\n\n```\n/tmp/tmpZsJCOP/src.linux-i686-2.6/tiswe_integratemodule.c: In function \u2018long_double_from_pyobj\u2019:\n/tmp/tmpZsJCOP/src.linux-i686-2.6/tiswe_integratemodule.c:149: error: expected \u2018;\u2019 before \u2018return\u2019\n```\n\nTracking down the problem, there is a single semi-colon missing in cfuncs.py that causes the error:\n\n```\n\\t\\t\\t(*v) = *((longdouble *)PyArray_DATA(obj))\n```\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 473043,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/thouis",
        "type": "User",

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nmount.swap on a on-disk swap file will always report Result: None even when the swap file is mounted, w/ persist: True.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n(Please provide relevant configs and/or SLS files (Be sure to remove sensitive info).)\r\n# Create swapfile\r\n```\r\n/swapfile:\r\n  cmd.run:\r\n    - name: |\r\n        [ -f /swapfile ] || /usr/bin/dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=4096\r\n        /usr/bin/chmod 0600 /swapfile\r\n        /usr/sbin/mkswap /swapfile\r\n        /usr/sbin/swapon -a\r\n    - unless: /usr/bin/file /swapfile 2>&1 | /usr/bin/grep -q \"Linux/i386 swap\"\r\n  mount.swap:\r\n    - persist: true\r\n```\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n(Include debug logs if possible and relevant.)\r\nRun above state, the first time it'll create a 4 GB on-disk swap file at /swapfile, add to /etc/fstab, and swapon it.  Subsequent runs show no issue with this state.  Running w/ test=True however, you'll get this:\r\n```\r\nlocal:\r\n----------\r\n          ID: /swapfile\r\n    Function: mount.swap\r\n      Result: None\r\n     Comment: Swap /swapfile is set to be added to the fstab and to be activated\r\n     Started: 12:11:44.588313\r\n    Duration: 6.851 ms\r\n     Changes:   \r\n\r\nSummary for local\r\n------------\r\nSucceeded: 2 (unchanged=1)\r\nFailed:    0\r\n------------\r\nTotal states run:     2\r\nTotal run time:  13.197 ms\r\n```\r\n### Versions Report\r\n(Provided by running `salt --versions-report`. Please also mention any differences in master/minion versions.)\r\n\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2016.11.5\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: 1.6.0\r\n       cherrypy: unknown\r\n       dateutil: 2.4.2\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: Not Installed\r\n      gitpython: Not Installed\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\r\n           Mako: 0.8.1\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.8\r\n   mysql-python: 1.2.5\r\n      pycparser: 2.14\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: 3.4.3\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov  6 2016, 00:28:07)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.11\r\n          PyZMQ: 15.3.0\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: Not Installed\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.4.2\r\n            ZMQ: 4.1.4\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: centos 7.3.1611 Core\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 4.9.30-1.el7.centos.x86_64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: CentOS Linux 7.3.1611 Core",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

mount.swap on a on-disk swap file will always report Result: None even when the swap file is mounted, w/ persist: True.

### Setup
(Please provide relevant configs and/or SLS files (Be sure to remove sensitive info).)
# Create swapfile
```
/swapfile:
  cmd.run:
    - name: |
        [ -f /swapfile ] || /usr/bin/dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=4096
        /usr/bin/chmod 0600 /swapfile
        /usr/sbin/mkswap /swapfile
        /usr/sbin/swapon -a
    - unless: /usr/bin/file /swapfile 2>&1 | /usr/bin/grep -q "Linux/i386 swap"
  mount.swap:
    - persist: true
```
### Steps to Reproduce Issue
(Include debug logs if possible and relevant.)
Run above state, the first time it'll create a 4 GB on-disk swap file at /swapfile, add to /etc/fstab, and swapon it.  Subsequent runs show no issue with this state.  Running w/ test=True however, you'll get this:
```
local:
----------
          ID: /swapfile
    Function: mount.swap
      Result: None
     Comment: Swap /swapfile is set to be added to the fstab and to be activated
     Started: 12:11:44.588313
    Duration: 6.851 ms
     Changes:   

Summary for local
------------
Succeeded: 2 (unchanged=1)
Failed:    0
------------
Total states run:     2
Total run time:  13.197 ms
```
### Versions Report
(Provided by running `salt --versions-report`. Please also mention any differences in master/minion versions.)

           Salt: 2016.11.5

Or what is wrong in my code?\n\nVersions: `python-2.7.10`, `pandas-0.17.0`, `openpyxl-2.3.0`.\n\nP.S. extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Hello all,

I want collect few tables into the one with pandas. I use the code presented below:

``` python
import pandas as pd
import itertools
import types

df = None
for frame in ['x', 'y']:
    df_ = pd.read_excel(u'%s.xlsx' % frame)
    df_ = df_.set_index([u'time'])

    parameters = list(df_.columns)
    tuples = []
    for tup in itertools.product([frame,], parameters):
        tuples.append(tup)

    columns = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples(tuples, names=[u'Frames',u'Parameters'])

    df_new = pd.DataFrame(columns=columns, index=df_.index)
    for par in parameters:
        df_new[frame, par] = df_[par]
    del df_

    if df is None:
        df = df_new
    else:
        df = pd.concat([df, df_new], axis=1)

df.to_excel('merged_xlsx.xlsx')
df.to_excel('merged_xls.xls')
```

Source data is `x.xlsx`
![x](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2182222/10658681/887a8df8-78b2-11e5-9ee8-8fe3b6057c3a.png)

and `y.xlsx` files.
![y](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2182222/10658680/88795dd4-78b2-11e5-9652-7a670ded97a0.png)

XLS engine works well (`merged_xls.xls`):
![merged_xls](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2182222/10658677/885b90ec-78b2-11e5-9e0d-34f9acb6f3a1.png)

But something is wrong (cells merging) with XLSX engine (`merged_xlsx.xlsx`):
![merged_xlsx](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2182222/10658678/885ba3b6-78b2-11e5-84fb-a60d9664b6f9.png)

Manual cells unmerging works in Excel:
![merged_xlsx_unmerged](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2182222/10658679/88603084-78b2-11e5-82d9-6674c480810f.png)

Is it bug in XLSX pandas engine (openpyxl)? Or what is wrong in my code?

Versions: `python-2.7.10`, `pandas-0.17.0`, `openpyxl-2.3.0`.

P.S. This issue is copy of [my question on stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33274716/pandas-exporting-to-excel-xls-xlsx-with-multilevel-columns). It was suggested as bug and was adviced to post here.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Pandas exporting to Excel (xls, xlsx) with multilevel columns"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "IO Excel",
            "description": "read_excel, to_excel"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "Trying to set a value on a mixed-type Panel4D currently fails:\n\n```\nIn [1]: from pandas.util import testing as tmd\n\nIn [2]: p4d = tmd.makePanel4D()\n\nIn [3]: p4d['foo'] = 'bar'\n\nIn [4]: p4d.iloc[0,0,0,0] = 0\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)\n<ipython-input-4-bb74b95f7244> in <module>()\n----> 1 p4d.iloc[0,0,0,0] = 0\n\n/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py in __setitem__(self, key, value)\n    119                 indexer = self._convert_to_indexer(key, is_setter=True)\n    120\n--> 121         self._setitem_with_indexer(indexer, value)\n    122\n    123     def _has_valid_type(self, k, axis):\n\n/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py in _setitem_with_indexer(self, indexer, value)\n    356             # indexer here\n    357             if (len(labels) == 1 and\n--> 358                     isinstance(self.obj[labels[0]].index, MultiIndex)):\n    359                 item = labels[0]\n    360                 obj = self.obj[item]\n\n/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/generic.py in __getattr__(self, name)\n   1927         \"\"\"\n   1928         if name in self._internal_names_set:\n-> 1929             return object.__getattribute__(self, name)\n   1930         elif name in self._metadata:\n   1931             return object.__getattribute__(self, name)\n\nAttributeError: 'Panel' object has no attribute 'index'\n```\n\nFortunately, it looks like a simple fix. If this looks OK. I'll add a note to `v0.15.1.txt` (doesn't have a GH issue number yet).\n\nThis fix is needed for my latest attempt at the fillna bug #8395.\n",

{
    "body": [
        "Trying to set a value on a mixed-type Panel4D currently fails:

```
In [1]: from pandas.util import testing as tmd

In [2]: p4d = tmd.makePanel4D()

In [3]: p4d['foo'] = 'bar'

In [4]: p4d.iloc[0,0,0,0] = 0
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-bb74b95f7244> in <module>()
----> 1 p4d.iloc[0,0,0,0] = 0

/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py in __setitem__(self, key, value)
    119                 indexer = self._convert_to_indexer(key, is_setter=True)
    120
--> 121         self._setitem_with_indexer(indexer, value)
    122
    123     def _has_valid_type(self, k, axis):

/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py in _setitem_with_indexer(self, indexer, value)
    356             # indexer here
    357             if (len(labels) == 1 and
--> 358                     isinstance(self.obj[labels[0]].index, MultiIndex)):
    359                 item = labels[0]
    360                 obj = self.obj[item]

/home/stahlous/pd_dev/pandas/pandas/core/generic.py in __getattr__(self, name)
   1927         """
   1928         if name in self._internal_names_set:
-> 1929             return object.__getattribute__(self, name)
   1930         elif name in self._metadata:
   1931             return object.__getattribute__(self, name)

AttributeError: 'Panel' object has no attribute 'index'
```

Fortunately, it looks like a simple fix. If this looks OK. I'll add a note to `v0.15.1.txt` (doesn't have a GH issue number yet).

This fix is needed for my latest attempt at the fillna bug #8395.
"

        "BUG: setitem fails on mixed-type Panel4D"

}

{
    "id": 32777682,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/7033",
    "body": "closes https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/5677\n\nAs a reminder, with a  data frame like:\n\n``` python\nfrom itertools import cycle, islice \n\nnp.random.seed(0)\ndf = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(20, 2))\ndf.columns = [\"foo\",\"bar\"]\ndf['g0'] = list(islice(cycle('ab'), 20))\ndf['g1'] = ['a'] * 10 + ['b'] * 10\ndf['g2'] = ['c'] * 5 + ['d'] * 5 + ['c'] * 5 + ['d'] * 5\n\ndf = df.set_index(['g1', 'g2'])\n```\n\nBefore if you wanted to groupby a a column and index level, you'd have to\n\n``` python\ng = df.reset_index().groupby(['g0', 'g1'])\n```\n\nNow you can just do `df.groupby(['g0', 'g1'])`. In ambiguous cases where a there's a key in `by` that's in both the index names and columns we warn and proceed with grouping by the columns (I haven't tested this part yet).\n",

    "id": 787769469,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/18179",
    "body": "<!-- Please describe the issue in detail here, and fill in the fields below -->\r\n\r\n### Reproducing code example:\r\n\r\n<!-- A short code example that reproduces the problem/missing feature. It should be\r\nself-contained, i.e., possible to run as-is via 'python myproblem.py' -->\r\n\r\n```\r\npytest -sv numpy/f2py/tests/test_callback.py -k 'test_all[t]' -r s -x\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Error message:\r\n\r\n<!-- If you are reporting a segfault please include a GDB traceback, which you\r\ncan generate by following\r\nhttps://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/source/dev/development_environment.rst#debugging -->\r\n\r\n<!-- Full error message, if any (starting from line Traceback: ...) -->\r\n\r\n```\r\nE                                  /tmp/tmphz3v9phb/src.linux-x86_64-3.9/_test_ext_module_5403module.c:75:10: fatal error: threads.h: No such file or directory\r\nE                                     75 | #include <threads.h>\r\nE                                        |          ^~~~~~~~~~~\r\nE                                  compilation terminated.\r\n```\r\n\r\n### NumPy/Python version information:\r\n\r\n<!-- Output from 'import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)' -->\r\n\r\n```\r\n>>> import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)\r\n1.21.0.dev0+438.gbf4ac1f81 3.9.1 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jan 10 2021, 02:55:42) \r\n[GCC 9.3.0]\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Additional information\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ ldd --version\r\nldd (Ubuntu GLIBC 2.27-3ubuntu1.2) 2.27\r\nCopyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.\r\n```\r\n\r\nC11 threads.h appears to be supported starting from glibc 2.28, see [here](https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=14092#c10).\r\n\r\nUndefining CPP macro F2PY_THREAD_LOCAL_DECL makes the test pass.\r\n\r\nA solution is not to define F2PY_THREAD_LOCAL_DECL for glibc version < 2.28 in numpy/f2py/cfuncs.py .",

{
    "body": [
        "<!-- Please describe the issue in detail here, and fill in the fields below -->

### Reproducing code example:

<!-- A short code example that reproduces the problem/missing feature. It should be
self-contained, i.e., possible to run as-is via 'python myproblem.py' -->

```
pytest -sv numpy/f2py/tests/test_callback.py -k 'test_all[t]' -r s -x
```

### Error message:

<!-- If you are reporting a segfault please include a GDB traceback, which you
can generate by following
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/source/dev/development_environment.rst#debugging -->

<!-- Full error message, if any (starting from line Traceback: ...) -->

```
E                                  /tmp/tmphz3v9phb/src.linux-x86_64-3.9/_test_ext_module_5403module.c:75:10: fatal error: threads.h: No such file or directory
E                                     75 | #include <threads.h>
E                                        |          ^~~~~~~~~~~
E                                  compilation terminated.
```

### NumPy/Python version information:

<!-- Output from 'import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)' -->

```
>>> import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)
1.21.0.dev0+438.gbf4ac1f81 3.9.1 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jan 10 2021, 02:55:42) 
[GCC 9.3.0]
```

### Additional information

```
$ ldd --version
ldd (Ubuntu GLIBC 2.27-3ubuntu1.2) 2.27
Copyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
```

C11 threads.h appears to be supported starting from glibc 2.28, see [here](https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=14092#c10).

Undefining CPP macro F2PY_THREAD_LOCAL_DECL makes the test pass.

A solution is not to define F2PY_THREAD_LOCAL_DECL for glibc version < 2.28 in numpy/f2py/cfuncs.py ."

body:
{
    "id": 61493644,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/5680",
    "body": "Noticed this while randomly reading through the source code to `mtrand.c` (as generated from `mtrand.pyx`):\n\n```\n~$ python3\nPython 3.4.2 (default, Oct  8 2014, 10:45:20) \n[GCC 4.9.1] on linux\nType \"help\", \"copyright\", \"credits\" or \"license\" for more information.\n>>> import sys\n>>> \"mtrand\" in sys.modules\nFalse\n>>> import numpy\n>>> \"mtrand\" in sys.modules\nTrue\n>>> import mtrand\n>>> mtrand\n<module 'numpy.random.mtrand' from '/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/numpy/random/mtrand.cpython-34m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so'>\n>>> numpy.random.mtrand\n<module 'numpy.random.mtrand' from '/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/numpy/random/mtrand.cpython-34m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so'>\n>>> sys.modules[\"numpy.random.mtrand\"]\n<module 'numpy.random.mtrand' from '/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/numpy/random/mtrand.cpython-34m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so'>\n```\n\nThe problem is the following code inside the Cython-generated module init function:\n\n```\n  #if PY_MAJOR_VERSION >= 3\n  {\n    PyObject *modules = PyImport_GetModuleDict(); if (unlikely(!modules)) {__pyx_filename = __pyx_f[0]; __pyx_lineno = 1; __pyx_clineno = __LINE__; goto __pyx_L1_error;}\n    if (!PyDict_GetItemString(modules, \"mtrand\")) {\n      if (unlikely(PyDict_SetItemString(modules, \"mtrand\", __pyx_m) < 0)) {__pyx_filename = __pyx_f[0]; __pyx_lineno = 1; __pyx_clineno = __LINE__; goto __pyx_L1_error;}\n    }\n  }\n  #endif\n```\n\nwhich is just... \"if this is python 3, then do `sys.modules[\"mtrand\"] = this module`\".\n\nI don't know why Cython does this. If you look at the above REPL trace, it's clear that the `mtrand` module does end up with a properly qualified `__name__`, and does end up in the proper fully-qualified place in `sys.modules` as well, so... maybe this is just a bug in Cython, and the C code I quoted above should just not be generated?\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 609896,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/njsmith",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "njsmith",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjYwOTg5Ng==",

        "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions",
        "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events"
    },

{
    "id": 272914535,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/44471",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\nWhen I do `salt '*' pkg.install vim` I got\r\n\r\n> root@e470 ~ # salt '*' pkg.install vim\r\n192.168.246.50:\r\n    The minion function caused an exception: Traceback (most recent call last):\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/minion.py\", line 1470, in _thread_return\r\n        return_data = executor.execute()\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/executors/direct_call.py\", line 28, in execute\r\n        return self.func(*self.args, **self.kwargs)\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py\", line 1284, in install\r\n        _available = list_repo_pkgs(*has_wildcards, byrepo=False, **kwargs)\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py\", line 792, in list_repo_pkgs\r\n        repo_name for repo_name, repo_info in six.iteritems(list_repos())\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py\", line 2466, in list_repos\r\n        filerepos = _parse_repo_file(repopath)[1]\r\n      File \"/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py\", line 2726, in _parse_repo_file\r\n        section_dict.pop('__name__')\r\n    KeyError: '__name__'\r\n\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\nminion setup\r\n\r\n> [root@localhost python35]# cat /etc/salt/minion\r\nmaster: 10.101.1.34\r\n\r\n\r\nmaster setup\r\n> root@e470 ~ # cat /etc/salt/master \r\ninterface: 10.101.1.34\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\nmaster version\r\n\r\n> root@e470 ~ # salt --version\r\nsalt 2017.7.2 (Nitrogen)\r\n\r\nminion version\r\n\r\n> [root@localhost python35]# /opt/alt/python35/bin/salt --version\r\nsalt 2017.7.2 (Nitrogen)\r\n\r\nI madesome debugging and found that the problem is with\r\n`section_dict.pop` function. If only I add the second argument to pop\r\n`section_dict.pop('__name__', None)`, then everything works.",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
When I do `salt '*' pkg.install vim` I got

> root@e470 ~ # salt '*' pkg.install vim
192.168.246.50:
    The minion function caused an exception: Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/minion.py", line 1470, in _thread_return
        return_data = executor.execute()
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/executors/direct_call.py", line 28, in execute
        return self.func(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py", line 1284, in install
        _available = list_repo_pkgs(*has_wildcards, byrepo=False, **kwargs)
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py", line 792, in list_repo_pkgs
        repo_name for repo_name, repo_info in six.iteritems(list_repos())
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py", line 2466, in list_repos
        filerepos = _parse_repo_file(repopath)[1]
      File "/opt/alt/python35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/salt/modules/yumpkg.py", line 2726, in _parse_repo_file
        section_dict.pop('__name__')
    KeyError: '__name__'


### Setup
minion setup

> [root@localhost python35]# cat /etc/salt/minion
master: 10.101.1.34


master setup
> root@e470 ~ # cat /etc/salt/master 
interface: 10.101.1.34

### Versions Report
master version

> root@e470 ~ # salt --version
salt 2017.7.2 (Nitrogen)

minion version

> [root@localhost python35]# /opt/alt/python35/bin/salt --version
salt 2017.7.2 (Nitrogen)

I madesome debugging and found that the problem is with
`section_dict.pop` function. If only I add the second argument to pop
`section_dict.pop('__name__', None)`, then everything works."
    ],
    "title": [
        "salt '*' pkg.install causes KeyError: '__name__'"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },

            "name": "P2",
            "description": "Priority 2"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nI would prefer if `user.present` would throw an error instead of trying to change uid and gid of an existing user. Currently, if an user already exists, it changes uid and gid values to new values. This might leave some files on the system previously belonging to the user with old permissions.\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n\r\n```\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2016.11.1\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: Not Installed\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: Not Installed\r\n      gitpython: Not Installed\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.9.4\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.8\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: Not Installed\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.10 (default, Jul 14 2015, 19:46:27)\r\n   python-gnupg: 0.3.8\r\n         PyYAML: 3.12\r\n          PyZMQ: 16.0.2\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: Not Installed\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.4.2\r\n            ZMQ: 4.1.5\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist:   \r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 14.5.0\r\n         system: Darwin\r\n        version: 10.10.5 x86_64\r\n```",

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\nI am using win_iis.create_app state to create nested webapps on IIS\r\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.win_iis.html#salt.states.win_iis.create_app\r\n\r\nIIS Structure is all follows\r\n\r\n>Default Web Site \r\n>>          / SubApp1\r\n>>>             / SubSubApp1\r\n\r\n\r\nIf SubSubApp1 exists, it fails with following error\r\n\r\n```\r\n----------\r\n          ID: create_subsite\r\n    Function: win_iis.create_app\r\n        Name: subapp1/subsubapp1\r\n      Result: False\r\n     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\state.py\", line 1905, in call\r\n                  **cdata['kwargs'])\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\loader.py\", line 1830, in wrapper\r\n                  return f(*args, **kwargs)\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\states\\win_iis.py\", line 627, in create_app\r\n                  apppool)\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\modules\\win_iis.py\", line 1433, in create_app\r\n                  raise CommandExecutionError(msg)\r\n              salt.exceptions.CommandExecutionError: Unable to create application: subapp1/subsubapp1\r\n              Error: New-WebApplication : Destination element already exists, please use \"force\" \r\n              parameter to override.\r\n              At line:1 char:34\r\n              + Import-Module WebAdministration; New-WebApplication -Name \r\n              'kiwiservices/stockser ...\r\n              + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\r\n              ~~~\r\n                  + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [New-WebApplication], Argum \r\n                 entException\r\n                  + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Destination element already exists, please use \" \r\n                 force\" parameter to override.,Microsoft.IIs.PowerShell.Provider.NewWebAppl  \r\n                icationCommand\r\n     Started: 09:49:54.431144\r\n    Duration: 1560.01 ms\r\n     Changes:   \r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nIt seems, it calling 'New-WebApplication' powershell, before checking if the subsubapp1 exists.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n(Please provide relevant configs and/or SLS files (Be sure to remove sensitive info).)\r\n```\r\ncreate_subsite:\r\n    win_iis.create_app:\r\n        - name: subapp1/subsubapp1\r\n        - site: Default Web Site\r\n        - sourcepath: C:\\subapp1\\subsubapp1\r\n        - apppool: SubAppPool\r\n        - require:\r\n            - file: create_sub_directory\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\nWhen creating nested webapp (i.e. webapp inside other webapp). It would fail if the subsubapp exists.\r\nCreate subsubapp\r\n\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\nSalt master version report\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2018.3.0\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: Not Installed\r\n       cherrypy: 3.5.0\r\n       dateutil: 2.4.2\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 0.6.4\r\n      gitpython: 1.0.1\r\n          ioflo: Not extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
I am using win_iis.create_app state to create nested webapps on IIS
https://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.win_iis.html#salt.states.win_iis.create_app

IIS Structure is all follows

>Default Web Site 
>>          / SubApp1
>>>             / SubSubApp1


If SubSubApp1 exists, it fails with following error

```
----------
          ID: create_subsite
    Function: win_iis.create_app
        Name: subapp1/subsubapp1
      Result: False
     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\state.py", line 1905, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\loader.py", line 1830, in wrapper
                  return f(*args, **kwargs)
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\states\win_iis.py", line 627, in create_app
                  apppool)
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\modules\win_iis.py", line 1433, in create_app
                  raise CommandExecutionError(msg)
              salt.exceptions.CommandExecutionError: Unable to create application: subapp1/subsubapp1
              Error: New-WebApplication : Destination element already exists, please use "force" 
              parameter to override.
              At line:1 char:34
              + Import-Module WebAdministration; New-WebApplication -Name 
              'kiwiservices/stockser ...
              + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
              ~~~
                  + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [New-WebApplication], Argum 
                 entException
                  + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Destination element already exists, please use " 
                 force" parameter to override.,Microsoft.IIs.PowerShell.Provider.NewWebAppl  
                icationCommand
     Started: 09:49:54.431144
    Duration: 1560.01 ms
     Changes:   
```


It seems, it calling 'New-WebApplication' powershell, before checking if the subsubapp1 exists.

### Setup
(Please provide relevant configs and/or SLS files (Be sure to remove sensitive info).)
```
create_subsite:
    win_iis.create_app:
        - name: subapp1/subsubapp1
        - site: Default Web Site
        - sourcepath: C:\subapp1\subsubapp1
        - apppool: SubAppPool
        - require:
            - file: create_sub_directory
```


### Steps to Reproduce Issue
When creating nested webapp (i.e. webapp inside other webapp). It would fail if the subsubapp exists.
Create subsubapp


### Versions Report
Salt master version report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2018.3.0
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: 3.5.0
       dateutil: 2.4.2
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 0.6.4
      gitpython: 1.0.1
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.8
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: 1.0.3
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.12 (default, Dec  4 2017, 14:50:18)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 15.2.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 0.9.0
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.1.4
 
System Versions:
           dist: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.4.0-1065-aws
         system: Linux
        version: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial

Salt Minion version report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2018.3.2

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 1.10.0
       cherrypy: 10.2.1
       dateutil: 2.6.1
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.3
      gitpython: 2.1.3
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.9.6
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: 1.0.6
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.8
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: 2.17
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 3.5.3 (v3.5.3:1880cb95a742, Jan 16 2017, 16:02:32) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
   python-gnupg: 0.4.1
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.3
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 2.0.3
        timelib: 0.2.4
        Tornado: 4.5.1
            ZMQ: 4.1.6

System Versions:
           dist:
         locale: cp1252
        machine: AMD64
        release: 2008ServerR2
         system: Windows
        version: 2008ServerR2 6.1.7601 SP1 Multiprocessor Free

"
    ],

body:
{
    "id": 316167199,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/47199",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nIn contrast to targeting by wildcard targeting by list outputs minions twice including an error:\r\n\r\n```\r\nroot@master:~# salt \\* test.ping\r\nsyndic:\r\n    True\r\nminion:\r\n    True\r\n\r\nroot@master:~# salt -L syndic,minion test.ping\r\nsyndic:\r\n    True\r\nminion:\r\n    True\r\nminion:\r\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\r\n\r\nroot@master:~# salt -L minion test.ping\r\nminion:\r\n    True\r\nminion:\r\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\r\n```\r\n\r\nOn the syndic everything works as expected:\r\n```\r\nroot@syndic:~# salt -L minion test.ping\r\nminion:\r\n    True\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe problem also prevents using lists in node groups.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n\r\n```\r\nroot@master:~# cat /etc/salt/master\r\norder_masters: True\r\nroot@master:~# salt-key \r\nAccepted Keys:\r\nsyndic\r\nDenied Keys:\r\nUnaccepted Keys:\r\nRejected Keys:\r\n\r\nroot@syndic:~# cat /etc/salt/master\r\nsyndic_master: 172.28.128.3\r\nroot@syndic:~# cat /etc/salt/minion\r\nmaster: 172.28.128.3\r\nroot@syndic:~# salt-key \r\nAccepted Keys:\r\nminion\r\nDenied Keys:\r\nUnaccepted Keys:\r\nRejected Keys:\r\n\r\nroot@minion:~# cat /etc/salt/minion\r\nmaster: 172.28.128.4\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\nPlease see above. No errors are seen in the log files.\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\nThis is the same for master and syndic:\r\n```\r\nroot@syndic:~# salt --versions-report\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2018.3.0\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: Not Installed\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: 2.5.3\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 2.0.0\r\n      gitpython: 2.1.1\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.9.4\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.8\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: Not Installed\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.13 (default, Nov 24 2017, 17:33:09)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.12\r\n          PyZMQ: 16.0.2\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: 2.0.1\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.4.3\r\n            ZMQ: 4.2.1\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: debian 9.4 \r\n         locale: UTF-8\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 4.9.0-6-amd64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: debian 9.4 \r\n```",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

In contrast to targeting by wildcard targeting by list outputs minions twice including an error:

```
root@master:~# salt \* test.ping
syndic:
    True
minion:
    True

root@master:~# salt -L syndic,minion test.ping
syndic:
    True
minion:
    True
minion:
    Minion did not return. [No response]

root@master:~# salt -L minion test.ping
minion:
    True
minion:
    Minion did not return. [No response]
```

On the syndic everything works as expected:
```
root@syndic:~# salt -L minion test.ping
minion:
    True
```

The problem also prevents using lists in node groups.

### Setup

```
root@master:~# cat /etc/salt/master
order_masters: True
root@master:~# salt-key 
Accepted Keys:
syndic
Denied Keys:
Unaccepted Keys:
Rejected Keys:

root@syndic:~# cat /etc/salt/master
syndic_master: 172.28.128.3
root@syndic:~# cat /etc/salt/minion
master: 172.28.128.3
root@syndic:~# salt-key 
Accepted Keys:
minion
Denied Keys:
Unaccepted Keys:
Rejected Keys:

root@minion:~# cat /etc/salt/minion
master: 172.28.128.4
```

### Steps to Reproduce Issue
Please see above. No errors are seen in the log files.

### Versions Report
This is the same for master and syndic:
```
root@syndic:~# salt --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2018.3.0
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.5.3
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.0
      gitpython: 2.1.1
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.9.4
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.8
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.13 (default, Nov 24 2017, 17:33:09)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 2.0.1
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.4.3
            ZMQ: 4.2.1
 
System Versions:
           dist: debian 9.4 
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.9.0-6-amd64
         system: Linux
        version: debian 9.4 
```"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Targeting by list (-L) broken for minions behind syndic?"
    ],

body:
{
    "id": 305721888,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/46568",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\nWhile investigating the issue https://github.com/saltstack/salt/issues/46236 I ran into another problem with the LGPO module. While trying to replicate the issue above, I modified some settings in the Local Machine Group Policy using `gpedit.msc` (Windows Server 2016). I modified settings in **Computer Configuration->Administrative Templates->Windows Components->App Privacy**. I changed 2 policies to `Enabled` and 2 policies to `Disabled`. Then I applied the state defined in the above issue. I was unable to replicate the issue above, but I did notice that the Group Policy objects that were set to `Disabled` were now reset back to `Not Configured`.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\nSet some policies in **Computer Configuration->Administrative Templates->Windows Components->App Privacy** to `Disabled`.\r\nMake sure `Configure Automatic Updates` is set to `Not Configured` **(Computer Configuration->Administrative Templates->Windows Components->Windows Update)**\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\nApply the state defined in https://github.com/saltstack/salt/issues/46236\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\nTested on 2017.7.3 and the HEAD of 2017.7 which would include 2017.7.4\r\n\r\n@lomeroe ^^^",

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nSince the upgrade from `2016.11.4+ds-2` to `2016.11.5+ds-2` on Debian Jessie the `ip6_interfaces` grains has become non-existant.\r\n\r\n`ip4_interfaces` and `ip_interfaces` are looking good.\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n\r\n```\r\n# salt 'gw02.*' grains.get ip6_interfaces\r\ngw02.darmstadt.freifunk.net:\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n\r\n```\r\n# salt-minion --versions-report\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2016.11.5\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: 0.8.6\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: 2.2\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: Not Installed\r\n      gitpython: Not Installed\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.9.4\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.2\r\n   mysql-python: 1.2.3\r\n      pycparser: 2.10\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.9 (default, Jun 29 2016, 13:08:31)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.11\r\n          PyZMQ: 14.4.0\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: Not Installed\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\r\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: debian 8.8 \r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 4.9.0-0.bpo.2-amd64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: debian 8.8 \r\n```\r\n",

        "### Description of Issue/Question

Since the upgrade from `2016.11.4+ds-2` to `2016.11.5+ds-2` on Debian Jessie the `ip6_interfaces` grains has become non-existant.

`ip4_interfaces` and `ip_interfaces` are looking good.

### Steps to Reproduce Issue

```
# salt 'gw02.*' grains.get ip6_interfaces
gw02.darmstadt.freifunk.net:
```

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
`timezone.get_offset` fails on AIX

### Setup


### Steps to Reproduce Issue
Running `salt '*' timezone.get_offset` gives:
```
salt '*' timezone.get_offset
AIX:
    date in salt binaries does not exist: /opt/salt/bin/date
```

### Versions Report
```
Salt Version:
               Salt: 2016.11.4
     
    Dependency Versions:
               cffi: Not Installed
           cherrypy: 3.2.3
           dateutil: 2.6.0
          docker-py: Not Installed
              gitdb: Not Installed
          gitpython: Not Installed
              ioflo: Not Installed
             Jinja2: 2.7.3
            libgit2: Not Installed
            libnacl: Not Installed
           M2Crypto: Not Installed
               Mako: Not Installed
       msgpack-pure: Not Installed
     msgpack-python: 0.4.5
       mysql-python: Not Installed
          pycparser: Not Installed
           pycrypto: 2.6.1
       pycryptodome: Not Installed
             pygit2: Not Installed
             Python: 2.7.5 (default, Apr 20 2017, 13:11:32)
       python-gnupg: Not Installed
             PyYAML: 3.11
              PyZMQ: 16.0.2
               RAET: Not Installed
              smmap: Not Installed
            timelib: 0.2.4
            Tornado: 4.2.1
                ZMQ: 4.1.6
     
    System Versions:
               dist:   
            machine: 00F62A684C00
            release: 1
             system: AIX
            version: Not Installed
```
"

{
    "id": 579316716,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/56356",
    "body": "### Description of Issue\r\n\r\nWith PR #53621, it is possible to reduce the frequency of `git_pillar` updates.\r\n\r\nHowever, `git_pillar` is not updated on server start, and one need to wait for `git_pillar_update_interval` to have the first run.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\nMaster config:\r\n```yaml\r\ngit_pillar_update_interval: 604800 # 1 week\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n- Add a new repo in the git pillar configuration.\r\n- Restart the master\r\n\r\nExpected behavior:\r\n- The new repo is available directly\r\n\r\nActual behavior:\r\n- The new repo is available after 1 week :disappointed: \r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n`v3000`\r\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue

With PR #53621, it is possible to reduce the frequency of `git_pillar` updates.

However, `git_pillar` is not updated on server start, and one need to wait for `git_pillar_update_interval` to have the first run.

### Setup
Master config:
```yaml
git_pillar_update_interval: 604800 # 1 week
```

### Steps to Reproduce Issue
- Add a new repo in the git pillar configuration.
- Restart the master

Expected behavior:
- The new repo is available directly

Actual behavior:
- The new repo is available after 1 week :disappointed: 

### Versions Report
`v3000`
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Refresh git_pillar on master start"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "Magnesium",
            "description": "Mg release after Na prior to Al"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-low",
            "description": "4th level, cosemtic problems, work around exists"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 150441351,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/32782",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nWhen a windows minion is asked to perform many command, sockets will not be released until load subsides, even though the job has returned. On my machine a simple test.ping every 5 seconds causes what seems to be some-type of starvation issue. Once load subsides, the sockets slowly get cleaned up and returned to the os.  Also, this leaves behind proc files in [saltDir]\\var\\cache\\salt\\minion\\proc.\n\nThis bug was introduced sometime between 2015.2.0rc2 and 2015.8.8. If you following the steps to reproduce for a minion running 2015.2.0rc2, you will see that there are no TIME_WAIT connections.\n### Setup\n\nCreate a master/minion setup with both running 2015.8.8. Make sure that minion has the following configuration:\nmultithreading: False\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\n\nWith a Windows 2015.8.8 minion running with 'multithreading: False', and a master running 2015.8.8,\nrun the following bash script on the master:\n\nwhile true; do\n  sudo salt saltminion test.ping\n  sleep 1\ndone\n\ntake periodic snapshots of the number of sockets in a TIME_WAIT and on port 4506. Let this go for a little bit of time, and you will see the number of TIME_WAIT connects grow. After some time, stop the script and you will see the number of TIME_WAITS subside. \n\nCommand on the windows minion to monitor this:\n`\nnetstat -ano | find \"TIME_WAIT\" | find /c \"4505\"\n`\n### Versions Report\n\n**MINION - extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

When a windows minion is asked to perform many command, sockets will not be released until load subsides, even though the job has returned. On my machine a simple test.ping every 5 seconds causes what seems to be some-type of starvation issue. Once load subsides, the sockets slowly get cleaned up and returned to the os.  Also, this leaves behind proc files in [saltDir]\var\cache\salt\minion\proc.

This bug was introduced sometime between 2015.2.0rc2 and 2015.8.8. If you following the steps to reproduce for a minion running 2015.2.0rc2, you will see that there are no TIME_WAIT connections.
### Setup

Create a master/minion setup with both running 2015.8.8. Make sure that minion has the following configuration:
multithreading: False
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

With a Windows 2015.8.8 minion running with 'multithreading: False', and a master running 2015.8.8,
run the following bash script on the master:

while true; do
  sudo salt saltminion test.ping
  sleep 1
done

take periodic snapshots of the number of sockets in a TIME_WAIT and on port 4506. Let this go for a little bit of time, and you will see the number of TIME_WAIT connects grow. After some time, stop the script and you will see the number of TIME_WAITS subside. 

Command on the windows minion to monitor this:
`
netstat -ano | find "TIME_WAIT" | find /c "4505"
`
### Versions Report

**MINION - (Windows):**
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.8

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1

**MASTER:**

body:
{
    "id": 147911788,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/32523",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nWe set grains_cache true, but the loader.py code sets the cfn after it tests if grains_cache is true, but then later in the grains def, you test for it again and it seems to have changed, therefore cfn isn't defined and it pops on that state.  If we move the definition of cfn up 3 lines, it works fine.     "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

We set grains_cache true, but the loader.py code sets the cfn after it tests if grains_cache is true, but then later in the grains def, you test for it again and it seems to have changed, therefore cfn isn't defined and it pops on that state.  If we move the definition of cfn up 3 lines, it works fine.  I am not completely sure this is the best approach however.

Here is my patch.

``` diff
diff  /tmp/loader.py /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/loader.py


558a559,562
>     cfn = os.path.join(
>         opts['cachedir'],
>         'grains.cache.p'
>     )
561,564d564
<             cfn = os.path.join(
<                 opts['cachedir'],
<                 'grains.cache.p'
<             )
```
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

    Function: network.managed
      Result: False
     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/state.py", line 1624, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/loader.py", line 1491, in wrapper
                  return f(*args, **kwargs)
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/states/network.py", line 413, in managed
                  grains_info = salt.loader.grains(__opts__, True)
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/loader.py", line 656, in grains
                  with salt.utils.fopen(cfn, 'w+b') as fp_:
              UnboundLocalError: local variable 'cfn' referenced before assignment

    Duration: 2632.383 ms

```

body:
{
    "id": 145915451,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/32349",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question

I get some "Exception [Errno 12] Cannot allocate memory occurred in scheduled job" errors in the log (reported to sentry). 

The munin graph below shows some clear patterns of a memory leak. 

Am willing to spend some time debugging this if needed (otherwise a @daily crontab restart of salt-minion probably will do the trick...)
### Setup

![screenshot_2016-04-05_09-31-47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/445200/14274403/714e2c02-fb11-11e5-940f-045ebb8d41ec.png)
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

It has about 10 of schedules such as this one : 

```
      smokeping-for-host.logilab.fr:
        args:
        - host.logilab.fr
        enabled: true
        function: lglb_network.ping_json
        jid_include: true
        kwargs:
          normalize_url: true
        maxrunning: 1
        minutes: 1
        name: smokeping-for-host.logilab.fr
        returner: master
        seconds: 0
        splay: 15
```

The master returner is the one published here : https://github.com/saltstack/salt/issues/12653#issuecomment-100673737

The custom module is as follows (converted network.ping to a dict/json output) : 

```
import salt.utils

def _normalize_url(url):
    ''' 
    Normalize URL, mainly so that carbon return can put them in single bucket instead of a hierarchy
    '''
    return url.replace('.','_')

def ping_json(host, timeout=False, normalize_url=False):
    '''
    Performs a ping to a host and returns the result as json

    CLI Example:

    .. code-block:: bash

        salt '*' lglb_network.ping_json saltstack.com

    .. versionadded:: 2015.5.0

    Set the time to wait for a response in seconds.

    .. code-block:: bash

        salt '*' lglb_network.ping_json saltstack.com timeout=3
    '''
    if timeout:
        cmd = 'ping -W {0} -c 4 {1}'.format(timeout, salt.utils.network.sanitize_host(host))
    else:
        cmd = 'ping -c 4 {0}'.format(salt.utils.network.sanitize_host(host))
    ret = __salt__['cmd.run_stdout'](cmd)
    try:
        last_line = ret.splitlines()[-1]
    except IndexError:
        # probably unknown host - TODO log warning
        return {}
    labels, results = last_line.split('=')
    labels = labels.replace('rtt ','').strip()
    results = results.replace(' ms','').strip().split('/')
    result_dict = {}
    for index, category in enumerate(labels.split('/')):
        result_dict[category] = results[index]
    key = salt.utils.network.sanitize_host(host)
    if normalize_url:
        key = _normalize_url(key)
    return {key : result_dict}
```
### Versions Report

```
# salt-call --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.8.2

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.4.0
         Python: 2.7.9 (default, Mar  1 2015, 12:57:24)
           RAET: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5
           cffi: 0.8.6
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.2
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.2
   mysql-python: 1.2.3
      pycparser: 2.10
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed

System Versions:
           dist: debian 8.3 
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.16.0-4-amd64
         system: debian 8.3 

```

        return {}
    labels, results = last_line.split('=')
    labels = labels.replace('rtt ','').strip()
    results = results.replace(' ms','').strip().split('/')
    result_dict = {}
    for index, category in enumerate(labels.split('/')):
        result_dict[category] = results[index]
    key = salt.utils.network.sanitize_host(host)
    if normalize_url:
        key = _normalize_url(key)
    return {key : result_dict}
```

body:
{
    "id": 5576596,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/1616",
    "body": "I'm not sure if it's possible to do this with some sort of a require and a cmd state, but... \n\nIt'd be nice if we could specify an arbitrary command for watch to execute when it detects changes, this is sort of in the same spirit as Issue #1122, but even more open than just a simple reload. I'm thinking something like:\n\n```\nnamed:\n  service:\n    - running\n    - enable: True\n    - watch:\n      - file: /etc/named.conf\n      - cmd: /usr/sbin/rndc reload\n```\n\nIn addition, it'd be great if the watch functionality could be extended to also include tests. \n\nThe use case I'm looking at is when configuration is being managed by multiple parties through something like a git repo, we'd want to be able to run some tests before kicking off the restart to ensure that the configuration is valid before we try to restart the service.\n\n```\nnamed:\n  service:\n    - running\n    - enable: True\n    - watch:\n      - file: /var/named/chroot/cf/named.conf\n      - cmd: /usr/sbin/rndc reload\n      - test: /usr/sbin/named-checkconf -t /var/named/chroot /cf/named.conf\n```\n\nMaybe with some fancy config manipulation I could achieve these, but I see a few places where this sort of thing could be handy if it's not already implemented somehow.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "I'm not sure if it's possible to do this with some sort of a require and a cmd state, but... 

It'd be nice if we could specify an arbitrary command for watch to execute when it detects changes, this is sort of in the same spirit as Issue #1122, but even more open than just a simple reload. I'm thinking something like:

```
named:
  service:
    - running
    - enable: True
    - watch:
      - file: /etc/named.conf
      - cmd: /usr/sbin/rndc reload
```

In addition, it'd be great if the watch functionality could be extended to also include tests. 

The use case I'm looking at is when configuration is being managed by multiple parties through something like a git repo, we'd want to be able to run some tests before kicking off the restart to ensure that the configuration is valid before we try to restart the service.

```
named:
  service:
    - running
    - enable: True
    - watch:
      - file: /var/named/chroot/cf/named.conf
      - cmd: /usr/sbin/rndc reload
      - test: /usr/sbin/named-checkconf -t /var/named/chroot /cf/named.conf
```

Maybe with some fancy config manipulation I could achieve these, but I see a few places where this sort of thing could be handy if it's not already implemented somehow.

    "body": "Calling state.highstate yelds on every run:\n\n```\n----------\n          ID: common_packages\n    Function: pip.installed\n        Name: docker-py >=1.4.0\n      Result: False\n     Comment: An importable pip module is required but could not be found on your system. This usually means that the systems pip package is not installed properly.\n     Started: 16:37:02.502184\n    Duration: 58.691 ms\n     Changes:\n----------\n```\n\neven though the sts is like this:\n\n```\ncommon_packages:\n  pkg.installed:\n    - names:\n      - htop\n      - python-pip\n  pip.installed:\n    - name: docker-py >=1.4.0\n    - require:\n      - pkg: python-pip\n    - reload_modules: True\n```\n\n(Masterless setup)\n\nVersions:\n\n```\nroot@trn:~# salt --versions\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2015.8.1\n\nDependency Versions:\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n           Mako: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.10\n          PyZMQ: 14.0.1\n         Python: 2.7.6 (default, Jun 22 2015, 17:58:13)\n           RAET: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 4.0.4\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\n       dateutil: Not Installed\n          gitdb: Not Installed\n      gitpython: Not Installed\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.3.0\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\n      pycparser: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n          smmap: Not Installed\n        timelib: Not Installed\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: Ubuntu 14.04 trusty\n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 3.13.0-65-generic\n         system: Ubuntu 14.04 trusty\n\nroot@trn:~# pip list  | grep docker\ndocker-py (1.5.0)\n\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Calling state.highstate yelds on every run:

```
----------
          ID: common_packages
    Function: pip.installed
        Name: docker-py >=1.4.0
      Result: False
     Comment: An importable pip module is required but could not be found on your system. This usually means that the systems pip package is not installed properly.
     Started: 16:37:02.502184
    Duration: 58.691 ms
     Changes:
----------
```

even though the sts is like this:

```
common_packages:
  pkg.installed:
    - names:
      - htop
      - python-pip
  pip.installed:
    - name: docker-py >=1.4.0
    - require:
      - pkg: python-pip
    - reload_modules: True
```

(Masterless setup)

Versions:

```
root@trn:~# salt --versions
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.1

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
           Mako: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.10
          PyZMQ: 14.0.1
         Python: 2.7.6 (default, Jun 22 2015, 17:58:13)
           RAET: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.4
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.3.0
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed

System Versions:
           dist: Ubuntu 14.04 trusty
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.13.0-65-generic
         system: Ubuntu 14.04 trusty

root@trn:~# pip list  | grep docker
docker-py (1.5.0)

```

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/27281",
    "body": "In:\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/develop/topics/installation/rhel.html#installation-rhel-repo\n\nThe yum repo is defined with the variable: $releasever, which expands to:  '7Server'\n\n```\nbaseurl=https://repo.saltstack.com/yum/rhel$releasever\n```\n\nBut the actual repo seems to be on: '7'\n\nhttps://repo.saltstack.com/yum/rhel7/repodata/\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "The following state fails, it looks like it is evaluating the fileproto incorrectly.

```
[root@salt salt]# cat pgsql/init.sls
postgresql repo:
  pkg.installed:
    - name: pgdg-centos94
    - sources:
      - pgdg-centos94: "salt://pgsql/files/pgdg-centos94-9.4-1.noarch.rpm"

postgresql package:
  pkg.latest:
    - name: postgresql94-server

  file.append:
    - name: /etc/profile.d/pgsql.sh
    - text: export PATH="/usr/pgsql-9.4/bin:$PATH"
```

```
[root@test salt]# salt-call state.sls pgsql
[INFO    ] Loading fresh modules for state activity
[INFO    ] Fetching file from saltenv 'base', ** skipped ** latest already in cache u'salt://pgsql/init.sls'
[ERROR   ] IFTTT Secret Key Unavailable, not loading.
[INFO    ] Running state [pgdg-centos94] at time 20:11:40.421451
[INFO    ] Executing state pkg.installed for pgdg-centos94
[INFO    ] Executing command "repoquery --plugins --queryformat '%{NAME}_|-%{VERSION}_|-%{RELEASE}_|-%{ARCH}_|-%{REPOID}' --all --pkgnarrow=installed" in directory '/root'
[INFO    ] Executing command ['yum', '-q', 'clean', 'expire-cache'] in directory '/root'
[INFO    ] Executing command ['yum', '-q', 'check-update'] in directory '/root'
[ERROR   ] An error was encountered while installing package(s): Path 's' is not absolute
[INFO    ] Completed state [pgdg-centos94] at time 20:12:01.676805
local:
----------
          ID: postgresql repo
    Function: pkg.installed
        Name: pgdg-centos94
      Result: False
     Comment: An error was encountered while installing package(s): Path 's' is not absolute
     Started: 20:11:40.421451
    Duration: 21255.354 ms
     Changes:

Summary for local
------------
Succeeded: 0
Failed:    1
------------
Total states run:     1
```

This appears to be only broken in develop, 2015.5 branch works fine.

```
[root@test salt]# salt-call --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.5.2-6472-gb72b392

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
           Mako: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.10
          PyZMQ: 14.3.1
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Jun 17 2014, 18:11:42)
           RAET: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.1
            ZMQ: 3.2.5
          ioflo: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
       pycrypto: 2.6.1

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.1.1503 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-229.4.2.el7.x86_64
         system: CentOS Linux 7.1.1503 Core
```
"

    "body": "Hello,\n\nGetting a `KeyError` when trying to do a network bridging under Ubuntu 14.04 with latest release (`2014.7.0`)\n\nThis is my state file:\n\n```\nem1:\n  network.managed:\n    - enabled: True\n    - type: eth\n    - bridge: br0\n    - proto: dhcp\n\nbr0:\n  network.managed:\n    - enabled: True\n    - type: bridge\n    - proto: dhcp\n    - use:\n      - network: em1\n    - require:\n      - network: em1\n```\n\nAnd the result:\n\n```\n          ID: em1\n    Function: network.managed\n      Result: False\n     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/state.py\", line 1533, in call\n                  **cdata['kwargs'])\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/states/network.py\", line 212, in managed\n                  old = __salt__['ip.get_interface'](name)\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/debian_ip.py\", line 1636, in get_interface\n                  adapters = _parse_interfaces()\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/debian_ip.py\", line 627, in _parse_interfaces\n                  if 'inet' in adapters[iface_name]['data']:\n              KeyError: 'data'\n     Started: 20:33:49.986165\n    Duration: 1.218 ms\n     Changes:\n```\n\nThanks!\n",

{
    "body": [
        "Hello,

Getting a `KeyError` when trying to do a network bridging under Ubuntu 14.04 with latest release (`2014.7.0`)

This is my state file:

```
em1:
  network.managed:
    - enabled: True
    - type: eth
    - bridge: br0
    - proto: dhcp

br0:
  network.managed:
    - enabled: True
    - type: bridge
    - proto: dhcp
    - use:
      - network: em1
    - require:
      - network: em1
```

And the result:

```
          ID: em1
    Function: network.managed
      Result: False
     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/state.py", line 1533, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/states/network.py", line 212, in managed
                  old = __salt__['ip.get_interface'](name)
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/debian_ip.py", line 1636, in get_interface
                  adapters = _parse_interfaces()
                File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/debian_ip.py", line 627, in _parse_interfaces
                  if 'inet' in adapters[iface_name]['data']:
              KeyError: 'data'
     Started: 20:33:49.986165
    Duration: 1.218 ms
     Changes:
```

Thanks!
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Network bridging under ubuntu fails with KeyError"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-low",
            "description": "4th level, cosemtic problems, work around exists"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "id": 53489339,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/19379",
    "body": "On CentOS7, the state will fail unless you manually create 99-salt.conf as outlined below.\n\nShould it perhaps be trying to use 99-sysctl.conf which is the CentOS7 default?\nEven so, it's not fortunate for it to fail if the file is missing.\n\n```\n          ID: vm.swappiness\n    Function: sysctl.present\n      Result: False\n     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/state.py\", line 1533, in call\n                  **cdata['kwargs'])\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/states/sysctl.py\", line 56, in present\n                  configured = __salt__['sysctl.show'](config_file=True)\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/modules/linux_sysctl.py\", line 86, in show\n                  for line in salt.utils.fopen(config_file_path):\n                File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/__init__.py\", line 1065, in fopen\n                  fhandle = open(*args, **kwargs)\n              IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/etc/sysctl.d/99-salt.conf'\n     Started: 08:26:27.292491\n    Duration: 146.792 ms\n     Changes:  \n```\n",

body:
{
    "id": 41639162,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/15415",
    "body": "I have 22 salt minions connected to a master. The behaviour I'm observing is this:\n\nWhen I'm actively using salt all minions react to e.g. test.ping no problem. However when they've been idle for a while e.g. overnight, it takes a couple of salt calls to get them all to react. It's as if they are being woken up?\n\nI couldn't find anything in the documentation about this behaviour and the minion log is empty without any kind of messages whatsoever.\n\nThe following commands have been executed without any pause in between them:\n\n```\n[root@kvm2 ~]# salt '*' test.ping\ntcub1404n42:\n    True\ntcub1404n35:\n    True\ntcub1404n23:\n    True\ntcub1404n25:\n    True\ntcub1404n40:\n    True\n[root@kvm2 ~]# salt '*' test.ping\ntcub1404n23:\n    True\ntcub1404n33:\n    True\ntcub1404n40:\n    True\ntcub1404n25:\n    True\ntcub1404n24:\n    True\ntcub1404n35:\n    True\ntcub1404n30:\n    True\ntcub1404n34:\n    True\ntcub1404n41:\n    True\ntcub1404n42:\n    True\ntcub1404n38:\n    True\ntcub1404n36:\n    True\ntcub1404n28:\n    True\ntcub1404n31:\n    True\n[root@kvm2 salt]# salt '*' test.ping\ntcub1404n42:\n    True\ntcub1404n34:\n    True\nkvm2.hv.de1:\n    True\ntcub1404n27:\n    True\ntcub1404n38:\n    True\ntcub1404n31:\n    True\ntcub1404n39:\n    True\ntcub1404n33:\n    True\ntcub1404n35:\n    True\ntcub1404n24:\n    True\ntcub1404n23:\n    True\ntcub1404n22:\n    True\ntcub1404n25:\n    True\ntcub1404n26:\n    True\ntcub1404n29:\n    True\ntcub1404n37:\n    True\ntcub1404n40:\n    True\ntcub1404n32:\n    True\ntcub1404n41:\n    True\ntcub1404n30:\n    True\ntcub1404n28:\n    True\ntcub1404n36:\n    True\n```\n\nIs this wanted behaviour or am I running into a bug? I was planing on using salt for service discovery (e.g. list all minions with grain role:zookeeper) but this makes it somewhat unreliable. But maybe I'm just failing to understand something about how job management works in salt.\n\nThe master is running CentOS 7 with salt-master-2014.1.10-4.el7.noarch (from EPEL)\nThe minions are running Ubuntu 14.04 with salt-minion 2014.1.10+ds-1trusty1 (from SaltStack's ppa).\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 2124094,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/lloesche",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "lloesche",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjIxMjQwOTQ=",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/lloesche",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "I have 22 salt minions connected to a master. The behaviour I'm observing is this:

When I'm actively using salt all minions react to e.g. test.ping no problem. However when they've been idle for a while e.g. overnight, it takes a couple of salt calls to get them all to react. It's as if they are being woken up?

I couldn't find anything in the documentation about this behaviour and the minion log is empty without any kind of messages whatsoever.

The following commands have been executed without any pause in between them:

```
[root@kvm2 ~]# salt '*' test.ping
tcub1404n42:
    True
tcub1404n35:
    True
tcub1404n23:
    True
tcub1404n25:
    True
tcub1404n40:
    True
[root@kvm2 ~]# salt '*' test.ping
tcub1404n23:
    True
tcub1404n33:
    True
tcub1404n40:
    True
tcub1404n25:
    True
tcub1404n24:
    True
tcub1404n35:
    True
tcub1404n30:
    True
tcub1404n34:
    True
tcub1404n41:
    True
tcub1404n42:
    True
tcub1404n38:
    True
tcub1404n36:
    True
tcub1404n28:
    True
tcub1404n31:
    True
[root@kvm2 salt]# salt '*' test.ping
tcub1404n42:
    True
tcub1404n34:
    True
kvm2.hv.de1:
    True
tcub1404n27:
    True
tcub1404n38:
    True
tcub1404n31:
    True
tcub1404n39:
    True
tcub1404n33:
    True
tcub1404n35:
    True
tcub1404n24:
    True
tcub1404n23:
    True
tcub1404n22:
    True
tcub1404n25:
    True
tcub1404n26:
    True
tcub1404n29:
    True
tcub1404n37:
    True
tcub1404n40:
    True
tcub1404n32:
    True
tcub1404n41:
    True
tcub1404n30:
    True
tcub1404n28:
    True
tcub1404n36:
    True
```

Is this wanted behaviour or am I running into a bug? I was planing on using salt for service discovery (e.g. list all minions with grain role:zookeeper) but this makes it somewhat unreliable. But maybe I'm just failing to understand something about how job management works in salt.

The master is running CentOS 7 with salt-master-2014.1.10-4.el7.noarch (from EPEL)
The minions are running Ubuntu 14.04 with salt-minion 2014.1.10+ds-1trusty1 (from SaltStack's ppa).
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "salt minions 'sleep' after some idle time?"
    ],

        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 23745934,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/9033",
    "body": "I have a pillar SLS which, among other things, defines the following:\n\n```\nroles:\n  - build-server\n  - salt-master\n```\n\nAnother SLS then includes the former under a key named `host1`. Pillar `top.sls` applies the former SLS to the minion with id `host1.org`, and the second SLS to all minions. When I run `salt host1.org pillar.data`, I see that `roles` has both list items (as expected), but `host1.roles` only has a single item (`build-server`). This causes my state logic to fail on `highstate`.\n\nSalt 0.17.2.2, Ubuntu 13.x\n",

{
    "id": 23671092,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/8985",
    "body": "The use of `LocalClient.cmd` is limited in ext_pillars. `ext_pillar` call never returns in the following example:\n\n```\nimport salt.client\ndef ext_pillar(minion_id, pillar, config):\n    client = salt.client.LocalClient(__opts__['conf_file'])\n    result = []\n    for _ in xrange(__opts__['worker_threads'] - 2):\n        ret = client.cmd('machine1', 'cmd.run', arg=('ls',))\n        result.append(ret)\n    return {'mypillar': result}\n```\n\nNow, the following command always times out:\n\n```\nsalt machine2 saltutil.sync_all\n```\n\nIf, however, `client.cmd` is called one time less, `sync_all` succeeds (# of worker threads minus 3). I believe there is something fishy going on, and salt's operation should not depend on the number of worker threads.\n\nI have found `saltutil.find_job` is posted to the bus before salt is able to read the last result but I could not why it happens or why it is bad.\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 383449,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/whiskybar",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "whiskybar",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjM4MzQ0OQ==",

{
    "id": 22783693,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/8590",
    "body": "Given a state to manage a file by salt, the resulting file that is copied to it's ultimate destination on the filesystem initially (albeit briefly) has 644 permissions allowing a window of opportunity for a local user to gain undesired access to the file's contents. Despite the state's mode specifying 600, for example.\n\nI first spotted this on CentOS 6.4 with Salt 0.16.4 on both master and minion (EPEL RPMs) but testing shows the same behaviour on the develop branch - last pull a couple of hours ago.\n\nSteps to demonstrate (on Gentoo here, in this case that's important):\n\nLogs, files, configuration are all running in a virtual environment created by pip.\n\n```\n$ cat srv/salt/files/secure.sls\nsecure:\n  file.managed:\n    - name: /home/grant/secure.txt\n    - mode: 600\n    - source: salt://files/secure.txt\n```\n\nRunning stat in another terminal (whilst calling `salt-call state.sls files.secure` in the virtual environment):\n\n```\n$ while true; do stat /home/grant/secure.txt 2>/dev/null --format=%a; done | grep -v '60'\n644\n```\n\nBecause the operation can be quick, it's not always easy to catch but on a slower system and with many more salt states I have successfully copied /etc/sudoers as a regular user using cat in a while true loop.\n\nThe source file srv/salt/files/secure.txt is just a file many lines of X chars.\n\n```\n$ ls -lh /home/grant/secure.txt\n-rw------- 1 grant grant 445K Nov 16 18:52 /home/grant/secure.txt\n$ wc /home/grant/virtualenv/salt-env/srv/salt/files/secure.txt\n  5758   5758 454882 /home/grant/virtualenv/salt-env/srv/salt/files/secure.txt\n```\n\n```\n$ pip list\napache-libcloud (0.13.2)\nJinja2 (2.7.1)\nM2Crypto (0.21.1)\nMarkupSafe (0.18)\nmock (1.0.1)\nmsgpack-python (0.4.0)\npsutil (1.1.1)\npycrypto (2.6.1)\nPyYAML (3.10)\npyzmq (14.0.0)\nsalt (0.17.0-4694-gae7e813, /home/grant/git/remote/salt-fork)\nwsgiref (0.1.2)\n```\n\nI believe files should be created with, at most, 0600 permissions and then the state mode (or internal default) applied once the file is successfully copied.\n\n---\n\nLooking through code I see some uses of shutil module copy functions (salt.utils also makes use of shutil). shutil.py uses open() on new files that seems to honour umasks, in isolated testing at least, and will create files with 644 permissions. So I have been experimenting with umasks in various places (primarily `salt/utils/__init__.py`) like daemonize(), copyfile() without success so far. Maybe `pip uninstall salt; pip install -e salt-fork;` isn't the best way to test or I am doing something wrong.\n\nSince `salt/modules/file.py:psed()` uses shutil.copy2 to create a backup file before editing, `file.replace` can also expose file content.\n\nI am still wrapping my head around the code and thought I would post this issue for review.\n\nBest regards,\nGrant\n",

{
    "body": [
        "Given a state to manage a file by salt, the resulting file that is copied to it's ultimate destination on the filesystem initially (albeit briefly) has 644 permissions allowing a window of opportunity for a local user to gain undesired access to the file's contents. Despite the state's mode specifying 600, for example.

I first spotted this on CentOS 6.4 with Salt 0.16.4 on both master and minion (EPEL RPMs) but testing shows the same behaviour on the develop branch - last pull a couple of hours ago.

Steps to demonstrate (on Gentoo here, in this case that's important):

Logs, files, configuration are all running in a virtual environment created by pip.

```
$ cat srv/salt/files/secure.sls
secure:
  file.managed:
    - name: /home/grant/secure.txt
    - mode: 600
    - source: salt://files/secure.txt
```

Running stat in another terminal (whilst calling `salt-call state.sls files.secure` in the virtual environment):

```
$ while true; do stat /home/grant/secure.txt 2>/dev/null --format=%a; done | grep -v '60'
644
```

Because the operation can be quick, it's not always easy to catch but on a slower system and with many more salt states I have successfully copied /etc/sudoers as a regular user using cat in a while true loop.

The source file srv/salt/files/secure.txt is just a file many lines of X chars.

```
$ ls -lh /home/grant/secure.txt
-rw------- 1 grant grant 445K Nov 16 18:52 /home/grant/secure.txt
$ wc /home/grant/virtualenv/salt-env/srv/salt/files/secure.txt
  5758   5758 454882 /home/grant/virtualenv/salt-env/srv/salt/files/secure.txt
```

```
$ pip list
apache-libcloud (0.13.2)
Jinja2 (2.7.1)
M2Crypto (0.21.1)
MarkupSafe (0.18)
mock (1.0.1)
msgpack-python (0.4.0)
psutil (1.1.1)
pycrypto (2.6.1)
PyYAML (3.10)
pyzmq (14.0.0)
salt (0.17.0-4694-gae7e813, /home/grant/git/remote/salt-fork)
wsgiref (0.1.2)
```

I believe files should be created with, at most, 0600 permissions and then the state mode (or internal default) applied once the file is successfully copied.

---

Looking through code I see some uses of shutil module copy functions (salt.utils also makes use of shutil). shutil.py uses open() on new files that seems to honour umasks, in isolated testing at least, and will create files with 644 permissions. So I have been experimenting with umasks in various places (primarily `salt/utils/__init__.py`) like daemonize(), copyfile() without success so far. Maybe `pip uninstall salt; pip install -e salt-fork;` isn't the best way to test or I am doing something wrong.

Since `salt/modules/file.py:psed()` uses shutil.copy2 to create a backup file before editing, `file.replace` can also expose file content.

I am still wrapping my head around the code and thought I would post this issue for review.

Best regards,
Grant
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "managed files are initially copied/created with 0644 permissions irrespective of mode."
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "fixed-pls-verify",
            "description": "fix is linked, bug author to confirm fix"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}
